  physical_appearance: This is a mirror. It is framed by wooden beams with engraved incised designs. The top of the mirror is decorated with a balustrade of small spindles. The top of the mirror features carved flowers and vines against a speckled background in a triangular shape. There are small carvings along the left and right side of the mirror frame as well.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan furniture cultural diffusion carvings (visual works)

  subject_terms_2: Mirrors Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Furniture

  subject_terms_3: Tan
 Kim Tian Furniture design

  sgcool_label_text: This mirror is framed by beams with incised designs
 including a balustrade formed by finely carved spindles. This is crowned by a gable filled with carvings of flowers and vines against a speckled background. With its features inspired by European architecture
 this mirror is a modest example of Peranakan hybrid tastes. Teak furniture whose designs were inspired by English styles was popular among Peranakans since the late 19th century. This mirror came from the collection of Botan House
 the ancestral home built by Tan Kim Tian in 1883 at the corner of Neil Road and Craig Road (since demolished).

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a mirror. It is framed by wooden beams with engraved incised designs. The top of the mirror is decorated with a balustrade of small spindles. The top of the mirror features carved flowers and vines against a speckled background in a triangular shape. There are small carvings along the left and right side of the mirror frame as well.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This mirror is framed by beams with incised designs, including a balustrade formed by finely carved spindles. This is crowned by a gable filled with carvings of flowers and vines against a speckled background. With its features inspired by European architecture, this mirror is a modest example of Peranakan hybrid tastes. Teak furniture whose designs were inspired by English styles was popular among Peranakans since the late 19th century. This mirror came from the collection of Botan House, the ancestral home built by Tan Kim Tian in 1883 at the corner of Neil Road and Craig Road (since demolished).
